These health care costs are squeezing too many families. Recently, we passed bipartisan legislation in the Senate Finance Committee to begin taking on Big Pharma. This is promising, but there’s far more work to do to ensure that our health care system works for all Americans.

Krista of Keene and her son both have a rare connective tissue disorder. Her son faces other medical challenges, as well. The two have medications that insurance won't cover, meaning they have to pay hefty fees out of pocket.

Laura also depends on a monthly shot. A single dose was originally priced at $35,000 before she negotiated with the pharmaceutical company. 
 
She continues to live in fear that the temporary agreement will shift, leaving her stuck with a hefty fee.

Laura of Hollis has lived with a rare disease since she was 8. Now 60, she has managed it through a relatively inexpensive prescription. But when a big pharmaceutical company bought the patent, the price raised to $1,500 a month. 
 
And that's not the only medication she needs...

I sat down with Laura and Krista in Peterborough to talk about health care costs. Time and time again, I hear outrageous stories from Granite Staters about the skyrocketing costs of their care.
 
Learn more about Laura and Krista's stories below 👇 pic.twitter.com/Ushzt1PTwV

This is a public health and safety crisis. Senator McConnell should convene the Senate immediately for an emergency session. He must allow a vote on measures to help prevent gun violence.
Multifaceted problems require multifaceted solutions. That is no excuse for inaction. There are common-sense steps we can take now. They will make a difference and save lives. #enoughisenough (4/4)
We also need to devote sufficient resources and attention to preventing and combating all forms of terrorism — whether inspired by foreign or domestic violent ideologies. (3/4)
We need to pass common-sense gun safety measures, such as requiring criminal background checks for all gun purchases and getting weapons of war off the streets. (2/4)
The causes of the epidemic of mass shootings in this country are multifaceted. But there are concrete steps we could take — today — to save lives. All that’s needed is the will to act. (1/4)

Every day that we go without addressing our nation’s gun violence crisis, more American lives are put at risk. This morning we woke up to news of a #daytonshooter. My prayers are with the victims, their families, and first responders, but without action that is not enough.

I am devastated to hear about the #walmartshooting in El Paso. My heart is with the victims & their families. 

Too often the response to gun violence is offering thoughts & prayers — but these victims, their loved ones, and all Americans deserve action.

At today’s Health, Education, Labor, & Pensions Committee hearing we’re talking about legislation to address:

👉🏻Surprise Medical Billing

👉🏻Prescription Drug Prices

👉🏻Transparency

👉🏻And Health Information Technology

These are vital priorities and we need to get this done.

These stories are so important – they show the flaws of our current health care system. 

I'm working on legislation like the STOP Surprise Medical Bills Act, the Affordable Medications Act, and the Fair and Accurate Medicaid Pricing Act to fix this broken system. 

5/5

Kassie broke down the cost of her son Spencer's diabetes equipment (see photo).

4/5 pic.twitter.com/4UbNaLhiRY

John of Hanover was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease in 2014. He then went on medication that costs him $750 a month. 
 
Even now that a generic drug has hit the market, his costs are still $570 a month! 

3/5

Sara of Dover had surgery in December of 2018. She told me that the hospital had confirmed that the procedure would be covered by her insurance. 
 
2 months later? She received a surprise medical bill of $700 because her anesthesiologist was out-of-network. 

2/5

Don Williams served as combat engineer, building bridges for the Allies in Nazi-occupied territories. Williams continued his service until 1946 and later trained as a mechanical engineer: https://www.concordmonitor.com/D-Day-Memorial-Day-Veteran-Profiles-Don-Williams-25758787 …

Joseph Bennett of Manchester arrived in Normandy 5 days after the Allies began the invasion and was later captured by German soldiers. He escaped and continued to serve until 1945. Today he lives in the Tilton Veterans Home: https://www.concordmonitor.com/D-Day-Memorial-Day-Veteran-Profiles-Joe-Bennett-25758841 …

Robert Barnard of Concord enlisted in the U.S. Navy on his 17th birthday – 16 months later he would fight on the beaches of Normandy. In June, Robert will be appointed a Chevalier of the Legion of Honor, France's highest honor: https://www.concordmonitor.com/D-Day-Memorial-Day-Veteran-Profiles-Robert-Barnard-25763256 …

Thank you to @ConMonitorNews for highlighting American heroes Robert Barnard, Joseph Bennett, and Don Williams who served on D-Day. These stories help ensure that their service will never be forgotten.

👉🏼Bicameral Congressional Trade Authority Act: It's a mouthful of a name. But to put it simply, it would require the President to get approval from Congress before taking trade actions using national-security justifications. So our businesses won't be hurt by unnecessary tariffs.

👉🏼JOBS Act: This bipartisan bill would help close the skills gap businesses are seeing. It would expand Pell Grant eligibility to cover intense, short-term job training programs aimed at boosting students career opportunities.

👉🏼Gateway to Careers Act: Republicans and Democrats alike understand the importance of training highly skilled workers — which is why we're coming together to fund community and technical colleges partnerships with workforce development partners, while supporting students.

I talked to @BIAofNH about the bipartisan initiatives I'm working on to support innovation in New Hampshire, like:
 
👉🏼The Gateway to Careers Act
👉🏼The JOBS Act
👉🏼 The Bicameral Congressional Trade Authority Act
 
What are all these acts? Read the thread for the breakdown.

I am also troubled that this proposal harms economic development, hinders our efforts to support innovative businesses, and undermines environmental protections.

President Trump is proposing to:

- slash $845 billion from Medicare (which he said he would not do)
- cut and cap Medicaid and end Medicaid expansion
- cut other important funding to combat the opioid crisis, including gutting the Office of National Drug Control Policy

I appreciate that the President heeded our calls to prioritize funding for State Opioid Response grants in his proposed budget. But, I am deeply concerned that this irresponsible budget proposal falls short in other priorities critical to the safety and well-being of our country.
